intro: Eupatorium benthamii, commonly known as the bentham's boneset, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its tall, erect stem and clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers. The plant typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along stream banks, thriving in moist to wet soil conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a rough texture, while its flowering period occurs during the late summer and early autumn. Eupatorium benthamii is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and support local wildlife.
